UI_visible_response: The May Fourth Movement, which erupted on May 4th, 1919, stood as a seminal event in Chinese history, marking a national campaign against foreign imperialism1. It was directed toward national independence, emancipation of the individual, and rebuilding society and culture4. One of the slogans of the movement was a call for 'Mr. Democracy' and 'Mr. Science,' representing the ideals of democracy and science2. The movement also signified a broader "new culture" movement that began around 1916, following the failure of the 1911 Revolution to establish a republican government3. On the day of the movement, more than 3,000 students from 13 colleges in Beijing held a mass demonstration against the decision of the Versailles Peace Conference, further emphasizing the push for national sovereignty and social reform5.
traffic_visible_response: The May Fourth Movement, which erupted on May 4th, 1919, stood as a seminal event in Chinese history, marking a national campaign against foreign imperialism [[1]]. It was directed toward national independence, emancipation of the individual, and rebuilding society and culture [[4]]. One of the slogans of the movement was a call for 'Mr. Democracy' and 'Mr. Science,' representing the ideals of democracy and science [[2]]. The movement also signified a broader "new culture" movement that began around 1916, following the failure of the 1911 Revolution to establish a republican government [[3]]. On the day of the movement, more than 3,000 students from 13 colleges in Beijing held a mass demonstration against the decision of the Versailles Peace Conference, further emphasizing the push for national sovereignty and social reform [[5]].
